Award.AwardTitle: GP-EXTRA: TU GEO Careers (Towson University Geoscience Educational Opportunities for Careers)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The predicted shortage of ~135,000 geoscientists in the US by the year 2022 means that it is essential to increase recruitment and retention of geoscience majors as well as improve preparation for the workforce or graduate school. This project is increasing undergraduate geoscience major recruitment through three mechanisms: 1) through partnerships with regional high schools and community colleges, and 2) through introductory geoscience classes by increased use of hands-on, active learning practices, and 3) through improved publicity about geoscience career opportunities, including teaching at the K-12 level. This project is improving retention through 1) academic advising at a program level to reduce barriers and foster learning communities, 2) developing peer networks, and 3) building of connections between Towson University (TU) geoscience students and the broader geosciences community. Cohorts of undergraduates engaged in faculty-mentored research serve as a core around which the geoscience programs at TU are being strengthened and grown. The cohort experience serves as a major tool to recruit and then retain students to geoscience majors. Undergraduate research experiences have been demonstrated to improve academic outcomes, interest in graduate school, and the percentage of students working in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM)-related careers. An increase in the number and diversity of students entering geoscience careers will help meet workforce demands for the U.S. economy.

This project builds on existing best-practice methods for recruitment, student engagement, and professional development to increase the number and diversity of students entering geoscience careers. Faculty from TU and partnering 2-year community colleges (2YCs) and high schools are working together to publicize geoscience majors and career opportunities to increase recruiting into TU geoscience majors. TU and 2YC faculty also are seeking to establish transfer pathways into TU geoscience majors, since 42% of current incoming TU students enter as transfer students. Evaluation of the results of these approaches is advancing knowledge of methods to broaden pipelines for geoscience students transferring from 2YCs to four-year institutions and serves to inform other institutions working on these transitions. Qualitative research of student experiences offers insights into which best-practice methods are most effective and why. This project will contribute to the relatively thin literature on extracurricular geoscience research experiences for students. By the end of the project, at least 18 students will be affected directly through the research cohorts. In addition, tens of students per academic year will be reached through the field trips and >500 students per year will be reached through recruiting efforts and pedagogical reform of introductory geoscience courses. Smoothing pathways from 2YCs to TU for transfer students will reduce the time students spend in college and the financial costs they incur, including students pursuing secondary teaching certification in Earth-Space Science. Underrepresented group participation in TU geoscience programs will be increased through recruitment from 2YCs with a higher percentage of minority students than TU and through the selection process of the cohort program, where consideration will be given to diversity and academic performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had the goals of increasing undergraduate geoscience major recruitment through partnerships with regional high schools and community colleges and through introductory geoscience classes by increased use of hands-on, active learning practices and improved publicity about geoscience career opportunities, including teaching at the K-12 level. This project also sought to improve retention through 1) academic advising at a program level to reduce barriers and foster learning communities, 2) developing peer networks, and 3) building of connections between TU geoscience students and the broader geosciences community. One driver for increasing recruiting and retention was the predicted shortage of geoscience graduates compared to projected job openings in the US. A second driver was improved preparation for the workforce and graduate school.

A key recruiting and retention approach was the formation of cohorts of undergraduates engaged in faculty-mentored research. These cohorts served as a core for growth of the geoscience majors at Towson University (TU). Undergraduate research experiences have been demonstrated to improve academic outcomes, interest in graduate school, and the percentage of students working in STEM-related careers.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the project had two core aspects: educational research and geoscience (disciplinary) research conducted collaboratively by undergraduate cohort researchers and faculty. The educational research focused on both qualitative and quantitative efforts to understand student motivations for choosing geoscience majors and the changes that they faced remaining in majors. Program building efforts were built on existing best-practice methods for increasing the number and diversity of students entering geoscience careers. The qualitative research is being published in the Journal of Geoscience Education and revealed that students? motivations were grounded in their personal interest in geoscience subject matter, enjoyment of being outdoors, undergraduate student research experiences, influential faculty in advising and instruction, influential courses they have taken, and post-graduation such as careers or graduate school. Challenges faced by majors included course selection and scheduling along with some program issues, many of which were already being addressed by the end of the grant.

Students were the lead authors and presenters on 21 of the 41 presentations and abstracts that resulted from this grant. The student abstracts were related to geoscience research. The two geoscience peer-reviewed research papers published thus far focused on the effects of urban land cover on stream chemistry, were published in top-tier journals, and are being frequently cited.

Broader Impacts: The number of Geoscience majors and graduates grew substantially over the grant period with 21 Geology majors in Fall 2014 and 39 in Fall 2020. The number of graduates per year increased from 3 to 10 over that same period. The Earth-Space Science major shrank slightly from 12 to 7 but the number of graduates increased from 0 to 3. The number of Geology track?Environmental Science majors (the third Geoscience major) grew from 5 in Fall 2014 to 9 in Fall 2020. Thirty-three individuals participated as cohort research students with 61 cohort experiences since most students participated for at least two academic years.

The cohort experiences also broadened the pipeline with the number of TU Geology graduates continuing to graduate school for the geosciences increasing during the grant period. Twelve TU Geology graduates from 2015?20 (10 who were cohort students) have gone on to graduate school for geoscience or related fields (e.g., environmental science), and at least four students in the process of applying for admission to graduate programs in Fall of 2021. By contrast, the PI is only aware of 5 graduates from 2015?20 who attended graduate school in the geosciences and related fields. Three TU graduates currently in graduate programs are from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups.

One contributor to the growth in geoscience majors has been the establishing of 6 articulation agreements with two-year colleges (2YCs) and intentional academic advising, particularly with entering transfer students. The connections built between TU and 2YC faculty are yielding increased recruitment and faciliating the transfer process for students. Increased experiential learning occurred through the writing of a laboratory manual for a physical geology class taken by >500 students per year (>80?85% being non-science majors). The more student-centered approach of the lab manual has provided an improved learning environment for students and instructors.

In addition to the benefits to students, the financial support for student researchers and purchasing of materials was valuable for multiple pre-tenure faculty, including three females, as they sought to establish their research at TU. The results of the geoscience research papers on urban stream water quality and chemistry have been of broad interest to watershed managers and regulators in the Mid-Atlantic and beyond.
